POST.QUOTE:
From what I understand its going to be a combination of live action with CG special effects. The movie hasn't shown up on the imdb.com yet. Right now I can only guess at the cast, as I said its in pre-production meaning the producers are negotiating for the money needed to make the movie and crewmembers for the film making are being selected. The last thing that's done before filming starts is the cast is selected. I heard rumors that a few LOTR alumni are being sought after for the movie.
Very very very rarely does a non-Japanese/non-Asian game/TV Show/Comic Book/Movie get translated into an anime. One obvious exceptions are "Witch Blade" the US comic book which was also made into a manga, and "The Animatrix" which featured anime shorts from the makers of "Ninja Scroll". I can't recall any others.

POST.QUOTE:
Let me make a few good viewing suggestions.
I liked Noir, it had high production qualities and had a more gritty indie film noir feel to its storyline. It didn't feel like an anime at all but like an animated version of a mafia crime drama or one of those Hong Kong John Wu movies.
As a Trek fan I loved "Stellvia" for its Isaac Asimov-ian approach to science fiction. The science and technology took a backseat to the story of the young girls and boys of the astronaut school just like in classic sci-fi literature and approached the sci-fi aspect of the series in a more rational and believable manner.
"Serial Experiment Lain" is a 1337-Speaker's cult classic which you must watch more than once to really understand what the hell is going on. The series predates The Matrix and may have been one of many anime that helped inspire it. To me it seems like it could have.
I really liked "Ah! My Goddess" the TV series. I've only seen season 1 and parts of season 2. Hild, Urd's mom, is supposed to make an appearance in the season 2 but I haven't seen that episode yet. So far this series more closely follows some of the manga storyline than the original OAV did. Season 1 has the Lord of Terror story arch near the end, Mara makes several appearances, and in season 2 Peorth in her manga persona appears early on.
One series I'm waiting for is "Sasami Maho Shoujo Club". Funimation is releasing it in the US next year. I'm a huge Sasami fan, she is in this series as a young girl who has magical powers but her parents don't want her to use them. She meets Misao who has her own special powers. They form a club for magical girls with Washu as their teacher and their mascot is Ryu-Ohki. A number of other girls join their ranks and they lots of adventures together. This series is very different from the Pretty Sammy OAV and TV series in that there aren't any villains and the story is character driven. I've only seen season 1 in the raw without subtitles and a 2nd season is already out in Japan.

"Michael \"TheZorch\" Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-12-19T21:10:03 This is a press release from the Anime Network posted on the AnimeOnTV.com group which is associated with the website that does TV listing for anime programs. The press release covers a free ad-supported online video-on-demand service from the Anime Network which has just launched into beta not long ago. YES FREE ANIME!! And, new stuff not yet available on DVD will be sown via this service too.
The full press release: ANIME NETWORK LAUNCHES NEW BROADBAND SERVICE
New Hit Series Gurren Lagann Leads Off Lineup
December 19, 2007 Anime Network, Americas #1 Anime Channel, today announced a new broadband service to stream high-quality anime on the Internet. This new service is free to the consumer, who can expect to find over 20 full episodes of classic and brand new anime series available at any given time. For the full range of Anime Networks Internet offerings, visit www.theanimenetworkonline.com .
Anime Networks online programming is ad-supported, with five or more new episodes rotating through every Thursday. The Networks lineup includes anime classics like Rahxephon and Saiyuki as well as new, ongoing series such as Ah! My Goddess: Flights of Fancy and Kurau Phantom Memory. Anime Network Online will present these series in their entirety over the coming months. Already more than 60,000 anime episodes have streamed since the beta launch in mid-November.
Beginning today Anime Network will broadcast brand new series over the Internet, including series that have not yet been released on home video in North America. These First Look Internet broadcasts, which will begin running months before the DVD series is launched, will feature the Japanese language track with English subtitles and.
Anime Networks inaugural First Look program is the much-anticipated mecha series Gurren Lagann, from Studio GAINAX (Neon Genesis Evangelion). According to Anime Insider, Gurren Lagann captures giant robot anime at its soaring, smashing, brilliantly explosive best, and its one of the few series rated Excellent by the readers of Anime News Network. The first DVD volume of Gurren Lagann wont hit stores until February 26, but fans can watch the first episode today at www.theanimenetworkonline.com .
We know theres a demand for fresh, unreleased anime on the Internet, said ADV President and CEO John Ledford. Through Anime Networks First Look broadcasts, we can engage fans in a lawful way and at the same time help build the audience for our DVD releases. Everybody wins.
Anime Networks streaming content is free and requires only the Flash 9 player and Java Script to view. As some of the programming is rated TV-MA, however, content is restricted to viewers 18 and older. At this time Anime Networks Internet offerings are restricted to the US and Canada.
About Anime Network
Anime Network, a subsidiary of A.D. Vision Inc. (parent company to ADV Films and Newtype USA), is Americas #1 Anime Channel, reaching more than 40 million households with thousands of hours of exciting, eye-catching serialized programming. Launched in North America in late 2002, Anime Network is the nations top video-on-demand (VOD) offering, and is also available as a 24/7 linear channel in several U.S. markets. The network continues to broaden its national roster of multi-system operator (MSO) agreements, bringing the elusive 1834, tech-savvy male demographic back to television and driving demand for additional digital services offered by MSOs. For more information, visit www.theanimenetwork.com .

POST.QUOTE:
Ok, that's what I thought. Maple Story is a very different MMO from say FFXI which has epic plots from the original game, the three existing expansions, and the new expansion which is coming out in a few days. Each one has a complete Final Fantasy game storyline complete with cinema cut scenes done with the game's 3D graphics engine. Now Maple, from your description doesn't have a set course you have to follow since it doesn't have a back story. FFXI is yet isn't like that, you can do quests in any order you please but you must do your nation missions in order (you can't do them any other way, but you can repeat them once you've finished them) because the missions make up the bulk of the game's storyline. What I'm trying to say is that they are both fundamentally very different from one another, ie; trying to compare them would be useless.
I prefer epic stories, but I guess MMOs like Maple which doesn't require massive amounts of free time would appeal to the casual gamer.

"Michael \"TheZorch\" Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-11-18T22:54:54 Speaking of FREE games I discovered something that has me really excited. My favoritest space combat sim "Freespace 2" has been resurrected. Volition, the developer who made the game, released the game as open source and a group at www.hard-light.net have been making a lot of major improvements to it. They took out DirectX and now use OpenGL and OpenAL with a lot of graphical improvements and sound improvements, ported the game to Windows, Linux and Mac, and updated the game's mission editor. The installer downloads the full free and legal Freespace 2 game updated with improved graphics, a port of the original Descent Freespace game to the new engine, and several mods. Overall it weighs in at 2.5 GBs.
Freespace 2 set a new standard for these kinds of games and 3D space combat sims today are often judged by it. The storyline of the game is what makes it great too. Best of all you don't need a super-powerful computer to play the game either. You can play it online if you know someone who also has the game. There is no server browser in it like other games but I'm sure its something that'll be added when new versions come out in the future.

QUOTE.PREVIOUSPOST: Min wrote: > Korean MMORPG are just a grind fest. You need to play 5 to 10 hrs > everyday for around 1/2 yr to get to max level. They are not meant > for people who has a life out side of the net.

POST.QUOTE:
From what I've seen of them this is true. They're nearly all cookie-cutter copies of one another except for Maple Story...which is also a Korean MMORPG. FFXI is a grind fest too through level 17 to level 30 range ... it called the Hell Range. You WILL die a lot when trying to level through that range Solo. Thankfully, SE is trying to change things so you don't need a full 6 member party to be able to level your character. The next update will let you pay in a party of 3 to 4 members and get the same results. I think you can Solo your way to the max level in World of Warcraft. You can Solo all the way to level 75 in FFXI only if you play the Beastmaster job which can charm monsters to fight by your side.
The Korean MMOs I've tried are: Kal Online Martial Heroes Flyff 12Sky Solstice

"Gold Dust Woman" <goldustwo...@gmail.com> 2007-11-19T22:25:28 they all don't seem the same to me. each mmorpg is different. of course they all have in common the fact that they are rpgs and u kill monsters to level and u play online w/ other ppl around the world. that's what defines an mmorpg. but there are dif classes. yes there are similar classes like warrior, mage, thief, etc. but not all games have the same classes. some add some, some take some. there are dif weapons, skills, armor. some have pets u can train. some of are 2d like maple, many are 3d. some mainly use the mouse to move around and do actions, some use more of the keyboard. some allow you to fly. some have pvp, some don't. there are endless differences among each one. all mmorpgs are grind fests cuz that's what they are all about--leveling. but i don't think the point is to reach the highest level. it's to have fun. u don't need to be pro to have fun. it's about meeting new people, trying new spells, wearing new clothes, challenging new monsters. ppl can play an mmorpg that takes days to level and still have a busy real life. u aren't required to play constantly 24/7. u can play whenever u want. i hardly play maple anymore. i just do it when i have time. that may be once a month. i don't mind. the game is always there for me when i wanna play, free of charge.

POST.QUOTE:
For a paid MMORPG FFXI has a monstrous level grind. Most of the big content in the game is for level 50+ characters. Thankfully the new expansion (have my copy on order from Amazon.com) Wings of the Goddess adds content that even level 10 players can participate in. Basically it takes you back in time 20 years to the Crystal War which is the back story for FFXI. A 2,280 file update was released last night adding a lot of badly needed enhancements to the game like the ability to run the game in a window so you can look up crafting recipes online while in the game and SE also gave us tons of new macro command slots, we really needed those badly.
Anyway, one MMO is probably enough for any one person to play. They take up a lot of time, I like giving new ones a little spin to see how they are but I don't play them on a regular basis. I stick with this one because 1, I'm a Final Fantasy fan, 2, I have friends who play the game regularly, and 3, SE announced that as long as people are playing the game they'll keep supporting it, updating it and will keep making new expansions.

"Michael Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-09-26T01:31:00 Just watched X-Play's Tokyo Game Show Special and there's a lot to tell you.
* No price drop for the PS3. Sony's CEO has made the decision to focus on getting more game developers to sign on to make titles for the system and to improve their online gaming service. Also, the Dual Shock 3 controller with the shock feature and six axis motion control was revealed at last. Sales of the Sony console have dropped so low in Japan that the usually slow selling Xbox 360 is now out selling it.
* Ninja Gaiden II for the PS3 was show. Its a true sequel to the original PS2 game, for once, and has some incredible looking graphics and a lot of blood and gore. The game-play featured Ryu running around with a big-ass scythe slicing up enemies at lightning speed in a distinctively God of War style.
* White Knight Stories for the PS3 is the sequel to the PS2 sleeper hit Shadow of the Colossus, it still features huge monsters you have to fight and you also have friends who travel with you to help. To fight the big monsters the main character calls upon a giant magical mech called the White Knight. This one looks interesting.
* Halo 3 was greeted by Japanese gamers with a slight yawn, but Square Enix & Tri-Aces' Infinite Undiscovery got a lot of attention. The game features a dynamic game world that is constantly changing and evolving around you as you play and even when you open up the menu screens. A few other developers showed off their games for the 360 and X-Play will be showing them tomorrow.
* Beautiful Katamari for the PS3 will feature larger worlds and online multi-player.
* The Legend of Zelda Phantom Hourglass for the Nintendo DS will be coming out in the US in about a month from now. Its a DIRECT sequel to Wind Waker and you play using almost exclusively with the DS stylus.
* A Bleach fighting game for the Wii looked really promising. Many of the series' characters are playable and it features a brand new villain made exclusively for the game who shape changes into Ichigo's friends in order to make them turn on each other. It uses some really good 3D cell-shaded anime style graphics and the fighting is fast and furious. The game is being developed by Sega.
* Soul Calibur IV for the PS3 and 360 looks fucking awesome! Not details are out yet on any new characters but the story focuses on both the evil Soul Calibur sword and the Soul Edge. No mention of whether there was going to be any online multi-player but the last I heard about this game it was hinted that there would be.
* Metal Gear Solid 4 - Guns of the Patriots got a lot of attention from TGS attendees. You may have seen game-play footage of it before, but Konami has refined the performance of the game to eliminate much of the low-frame rate scenes shown as the 2006 E3 Expo. There was a playable demo of the game and those who tried it all testified that the control was solid. A trailer for Metal Gear Online was also shown.
* Final Fantasy XIII's story will be split over three games. The titles for two of them are know; Final Fantasy XIII and Final Fantasy XIII Vs. The game is set in a world where technology and magic are at odds with one another and a young prince is trying to protect the last of the Crystals Temples. The short battle sequence seen at E3 '06 WAS ACTUAL GAME-PLAY AND NOT PRE-RENDERED VIDEO.
I'll post more when I see tomorrows follow up show on G4 at 8pm.

I don't have the cash but I'd like to get PS3 for two good reasons.
1. "The Orange Box" by Valve - Contains the PS3 versions of Half-Life 2, the Half-Life 2 Episode expansions, Half-Life 2 Multi-player, and Team Fortress 2. TF2 is a team based multi-player adaptation of the classic Quake mod that pit two or more teams against one another to do battle and to complete certain objective. Players get to choose different classes to play as; The Scout who was quick and nimble but didn't have much armor protection, The Commando with his heavy rocket launcher, The Spy with his knock out darts and ability to disguise himself as members of the other team, The Engineer who could build ammo dispensers and automated sentry guns, The Medic who could run around healing up team members or give enemies a disease, The Heavy Gunner with his mini-gun that turned enemies into hamburger, and The Demolishion Expert who can set charges to blow in walls and has a deadly grenade launcher.
2. "Unreal Tournament 3" by Epic Games - Actually the 4th incarnation of the UT series this game features the new, immensely powerful Unreal 3.0 graphics engine. It builds off of the success of UT2k4 which perfected game-play with vehicles and added the incredibly popular Onslaught match to the game. UT3 features a revamped Onslaught, Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Double Domination (teams hold certain parts of a map to earn points), and Assault gets another upgrade. My PC can't run the new engine but the PS3 and 360 can.

Cry me a river!
Tokyo Game Show G4 Coverage Day 2!!
The highlights:
For the PS3 * "Assassins Creed" got the attention of praise of the Japanese. They loved the intricate level of detail in the game which appealed to them a great deal. * "Devil May Cry 4" will introduce a new character and looks really cool. * "Resident Evil 5" looked incredibly life like and more terrifying than any of the previous games. Its a direct sequel to RE4. * "Virtua Fighter 5" was shown at the TGS and looked impressive. * "Little Big Planet" is a cute and imaginative platform jumping puzzle game which includes a level editor and each level other users make will be shared online so others can play them also. The graphics are really impressive. * "Grand Toursimo Prologue" completely blew me away. I played GT4 on the PS2 and incredibly enough it had an HD mode for 1080i, but this game looked REAL. There isn't much known about what will be in the game other than the fact that it looks awesome.
For the PSP * "Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII" actually helped earn the failing PSP some support from Japanese players. The game, in full 3D, is a prequel to FFVII. * "Godzilla: Unleashed" will include 22 monsters in this fighting game and it will also be ported to the Wii, PS2, PSP and DS. * "Secret Agent Crank" stars Crank from the Ratchet and Crank series who must save Ratchet who was arrested for a crime he didn't commit.
For the DS * "Ninja Gaiden" will use the touch screen to control Ryu. The backgrounds will be pre-rendered so that the handheld will have more power to focus on its intricate 3D animated characters. * "Metal Slug 7" was announced. * "Bomberman Land" consists of 40 mini-games which you can play alone or with friends. Its also coming to the Wii and PSP.
For the 360 * "Lost Odyssey" gained the 360 some support among finicky Japanese gamers. The US made RPG is designed much like a Japanese RPG and looked really good. The game world is a mix of magic and steam punk. Nothing was revealed about the storyline yet. What we do know is that this game is so big it will span 4 DVDs.
For the Wii * "Sonic & Mario" is the crossover game from Sega everyone knew was eventually coming. An announcement was made but game-play footage was shown. * "Resident Evil: Umbrella Chronicles" is a ride-the-rails "House of the Dead" style game where you blast away at zombies that come at your from everywhere. Its by far the goriest and possibly the most detailed game for the Wii yet. The game chronicles the fall of the Umbrella Corporation. * "Final Fantasy Tactics A2" brings the FF RTS game to the Wii with a new battle system, new jobs, and will be out in 2008. * "Fatal Frame" comes to the Wii and is every bit as creepy as the PS2 version. This isn't a remake of the original but a whole new title and will take advantage of the Wii Remote for some unique control schemes.
For more info goto http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/index.html

Have you ever watched kids On a merry-go-round? Or listened to the rain Slapping on the ground? Ever followed a butterfly's erratic flight? Or gazed at the sun into the fading night?
Do you run through each day On the fly? When you ask "How are you?" Do you hear the reply? When the day is done, Do you lie in your bed With the next hundred chores, Running through your head?
Ever told your child, We'll do it tomorrow? And in your haste, Not see his sorrow? Ever lost touch, Let a good friendship die Cause you never had time To call and say "Hi"?
When you run so fast to get somewhere You miss half the fun of getting there. When you worry and hurry through your day, It is like an unopened gift....Thrown away. Life is not a race. Do take it slower Hear the music Before the song is over.

BODY.HEADLINE: Funimation Voice Actor Randy Tallman Passes Away

TEXT.POST:
"Michael \"TheZorch\" Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-12-11T01:36:36 Voice actress Caitlin Glass reported on the AnimeOnDVD.com forums on Sunday night that fellow character voice Randy Tallman had passed away on November 20. He was 67. In addition to his deep involvement with the theater community and Shakespearean productions in the Dallas area, he had voiced roles in about two dozen Funimation productions. Among his credits were MoonPhase's Ryuuhei, Tsubasa: RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE's Fei Wong Reed, and Case Closed's Booker Kudo.
A memorial service was held at the Dallas Children's Theater's Rosewood Center for Family Arts on Monday, December 10 at 6:00 p.m.
Original Announcement: http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-12-10/funimation-voice-acto...
Randy's IMDb.com page: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0848193/
-- Michael "TheZorch" Haney thezo ... @gmail.com http://thezorch.googlepages.com/home AIM: thezo ... @gmail.com Yahoo IM: zorchhaney ICQ: 343230252 GoogleTalk: thezorch MSN Messeger: haneymich ... @hotmail.com:

TEXT.POST:
"Michael Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-09-21T12:29:00 I recently learned that will be three new KH games coming out. They were announced at the Tokyo Game Show.
One is for cellphones, one is for the DS and one is for the PSP.
"Kingdom Hearts: Coded" is the cellphone game. It takes place immediately after the original KH. Jimminey Cricket's journal is digitized by the king to find the secret behind a mysterious message. You play a digitized Sora in the journal who must find the answers.
"Kingdom Hearts: 358/2 Days" for the DS is set during the time immediately after Sora goes into that long sleep. You play as members of Organization XIII and the game features multi player mode.
"Kingdom Hearts: Birth by Sleep" is a prequel to the original Kingdom Hearts on the PSP and is set in the distant past when there were more Keyblade Masters roaming the world.
The trailers for all three were seen at the Tokyo Game Show but I haven't found anywhere you can see them online. Its possible that X-Play's Tokyo Game Show specials next week will show them. They come on Tuesday and Wednesday on the G4 network at about 8pm. Monday is the Halo 3 Launch Countdown running from 8 to midnight.
I set the DVR here to record them.

POST.QUOTE:
1. RMT is a violation of the SquareEnix PlayOnline user agreement. 2. Most RMTers use 3rd party software tools to claim NMs faster than regular players making it impossible for legitimate players to have a chance at fighting them. 3. RMT damages the in game economy which is very important in FFXI due to the immensely intricate crafting system it uses and the in-game Auction Houses.
Its such a serious problem that SE set up a Task Force to investigate players who deal in RMT and buy in-game money with real money. About twice a month they ban over 3,000+ users for violations of the user agreement and they are collecting information about the owners and operators of websites that sell in-game money, items, and characters so they can take them to court.

QUOTE.PREVIOUSPOST: Min wrote: > What 3rd party software??? I think people are just being whiny > because they are not good enough to get those items. I know people > who does RMT. They work their ass off for it. It's not like a walk > in the park for them.

POST.QUOTE:
There are packet sniffers which watch for the data packets that tell the FFXI game client when an NM is about POP (appear). There are bot programs to automate the process of fishing and crafting. There are tools that hack into the data stream between the game client and server and allow players to instantly warp from place to another. These 3rd party programs interfere with the data coming from the server and has been known to cause problems in the past like dropped connections and severe game lag. There are 3rd party tools for Maple Story also. Before the RMT problem became really serious I was able to make 20,000 gil in about a day or two by farming items from mobs, killing mobs that naturally drop gil, and crafting. Today, I am lucky if I make 20,000 in a month if at all and I need a lot of gil if I am to get new gear as I advance in levels.

POST.QUOTE:
Drops from mobs in FFXI don't fall to the ground, they go directly to your inventory slots. The big thing SE is really anal about is the game's balance, its a philosophy which dominates the entire game ... no one player is allowed an unfair advantage over the other, no exceptions.. RMT & 3rd Party Tools creates this imbalance. RMT makes regular in-game gil worthless and drives down the prices of items in the Auction Houses making it hard for players how make money by crafting items very hard if not impossible. Who would want to go out and level their crafting skills, farm the items, and craft armor, food for buffs, weapons, furniture (used to add storage in your Mog House), potions to cure wounds and remove poison and whatnot if you can just got a website pay $20 for a million gil and be done with it. OR, worst yet, goto a website and pay $50 to $100 for a level 75 character then get into the game. People will know immediately that you bought your character because there is a strategy you must learn to using the special abilities each character can perform and if you don't know these strategies people notice immediately.
Maple Story and other games probably aren't as dependent on a strong in-game economy as FFXI is. Does Maple have an Auction House? FFXI is 100% dependent on its in-game economy and if it suffers everyone suffers. Lower Auction House prices might be a boon to people who don't craft but eventually those people will need to make serious money and will need to level their crafting skills at some point and then they'll discover why RMT is such a serious problem.
It equates to counterfeiting. If someone dumped a few billion dollars of fake money into the US economy watch as it severely impacts it until those bills are found and removed, and the very act of removing billions of fake bank notes from the economy itself will have a negative effect also. FFXI's economy is modeled after the real world and its just as vulnerable.

Pretty soon it'll be illegal in Korea and similar legislation is being considered for the US and Japan. I've seen reports on the biggest RMT company IGE which sells WoW gold and FFXI gil. They literally run sweatshops in China where people sit in front of computers all day in a huge warehouse doing nothing but farming, fishing, and transfering in game money from one character to the next to keep one step ahead of the game admins. In FFXI, if you caught dealing in RMT of any kind you are banned and your character and player account is deleted as well as your CD-Key for installing the game is banned too. Not only that but the same report says that 70% of the credit cards used by RMT groups in all MMOs, not just FFXI, are stolen. RMT groups account for about 10 - 15% of the yearly Identity Theft cases throughout the year and less than 1% ever go on trail because they are all overseas.

POST.QUOTE:
I noticed that ALL of the free MMOs, with the exception of Guild Wars, sell game items and in-game money as revenue. Nearly all of the Korean free-to-play MMOs do this. NCSoft's free MMORPGs are the only exception to this as far as I can tell. Guild Wars isn't like your average MMO either, its sorts of a hybrid between a singleplayer RPG and an MMORPG. The expansions don't add to the game like expansions to other MMOs, they're each a standalone game that doesn't require the original Guild Wars. That's pretty unusual for this kind of game. I think 12Sky will eventually have a store for selling items too like so many other free MMOs, but its so early in its beta cycle right now I don't know what they plan to do with it.

POST.QUOTE:
I bought a copy of the game. The zones in town are full multiplayer areas, but the game world outside the cities are isolated so only you, your party members, or any NPC buddies you bring along inhabit the game world. They wanted to get rid of old tired MMO concepts like spawn camping monsters and having to compete with other parties over mobs. I haven't played it in a while, I like more traditional MMOs were you get to interact with people wherever you go in the game world and not just in the cities. This is sort of similar to how Diablo 2 worked in multiplayer, like Min just said.
Now, if you make a PvP character in Guild Wars that environment is all multiplayer but there is no roleplaying.

BODY.HEADLINE: Yuri Manga Anthology "Yuri Monogatari 5" to Premiere at Yurisai

TEXT.POST:
Yuricon_PR <spacet...@gmail.com> 2007-09-14T20:53:00 Yuri Manga Anthology "Yuri Monogatari 5" to Premiere at Yurisai
ALC Publishing, the world's only publisher of 100% Yuri, will be premiering their newest Yuri manga anthology, "Yuri Monogatari 5," at Yuricon's 2007 "Yurisai" event on September 29, 2007 at the Newark Gateway Hilton.
"Yuri Monogatari 5" includes stories by Japanese doujinshi circles UKOZ and Sakuraike, and features the return of Eriko Tadeno (WORKS) and Yurisai Guests Rica Takashima (Rica 'tte Kanji!?) and Althea Keaton. "YM5" includes fourteen stories of lesbian life and love by artists and writers from Japan, Europe and North America.
"Yuri Monogatari 5" is available online at the Yuricon shop and for pre-order on Amazon.com, and at comic and chain bookstores near you.
ALC Publishing was founded in 2003 to create and disseminate high- quality Yuri manga to the worldwide English speaking audience. ALC is a division of Yuricon, a celebration of Yuri and shoujoai in anime and manga.
For more information on ALC Publishing's 100% yuri publications or on Yuricon's "Yurisai" event, please visit our website at http://www.anilesbocon.com or email us at anilesboco ... @hotmail.com

"Michael Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-09-02T15:30:00 "Wings of the Goddess" will be the 4th expansion for the Final Fantasy XI MMORPG for PS2, PC and Xbox360. Details will be annoinced a this year's Final Fantasy Fan Festival in Anaheim, CA. Over 100,000 attended FF FanFest '06 when the 3rd expansion "Treasures of Aht Urghan" was released.
WOTG will reported take players back in time during the great war against the Shadow Lord and his army of beastmen. There are many rumors including the game having open PvP, and Beseiged (a popular game added with the Aht Urghan expansion pitting players against an invading army) style games in the game's najor cities of Bastok, Windhurst, and San'doria. SE confirms two new jobs will be added. Rumors suggest one could be a Time Mage.
Recent updates to FFXI have improved Chocobo breeding, added PvP Chocobo racing and race betting, and improvements to several jobs making them more powerful and better well balanced. One major change is the lifting of the experience point penalty on Beastmaster when they fight using a charmed pet.
If you can handle $12 a month I'd recommend you try FFXI. Things are gonna get real intetesting with the new expansion coming this Fall.

TEXT.POST:
Yuricon_PR <spacet...@gmail.com> 2007-08-31T00:41:00 Only 30 days left until the only 100% Yuri day of 2007!
Pre-registration for Yuricon's 2007 "Yurisai" event has just about a week left - the last day to pre-register is Sept. 7th. Pre-register at http://yc07.eventbrite.com . At the door registration will open at 9AM on September 29, 2007, at the Gateway Hilton in Newark, NJ.
At the Yurisai, you'll get to enjoy the largest library of Yuri manga and doujinshi - some of which has never before been seen in America.For more details about our Yuri Library and our policies and FAQs, please visit our event page at http://www.yuricon.org/events/07index.html
And time is also counting down on the Yurisai Poster and Fanfiction Contests. Our theme is, quite naturally, "Fairs and Festivals". We know that you'll have a great time at our Festival of Lilies, and we want to see your artwork and stories showing our mascots Yuriko and Midori enjoying fairs and festivals too. Ferris Wheels or goldfish scooping, running with the bulls or watching fireworks over a lake - you decide the festival and show and tell us all about it. Check out the contest rules and deadlines here on the "Yurisai" page.
Poster contest: http://www.yuricon.org/events/07Art.html Fanfiction contest: http://www.yuricon.org/events/07FF.html

Maybe if I create one with a few points it'll be enough to hold interest nya on a few at the same time or atleast create enough confusion on different discussions being held on at the same time to blend in well with the rest of the subject.
*Anime and TV shows. Other then the obvious, the fact that its animated and from Japan is there any real difference anymore between anime and 'live action' TV? Anyone seen Monster, its about a doctor who saves the life of a kid who incidentally butchered his parents and grows up to become this hell psycho killer and the doctor takes it on himself to hunt him down. There style of animation is pretty normal and I'm watching it thinking why is it animated. With such a broad range of topics and themes for anime is there really a way we can describe what is anime that makes it so special?
*Popularity Okay, anime used to be some sort of cult interest and when Naruto first came out with its original few arcs before the fillers came it, it was pretty awesome. Now adays, with kids putting on leaf headbands and pretending to be a ninja it kinda devalues it to me. Is it wrong, as a fan to want it to stay underground? How would you feel is anime became something like those idol shows that lots and lots of stupid people watch. I understand it may be that way in Japan though...
*Originality. Do you think the Japanese like the rest of the world are losing their originality? We see the same recycled characters over and over again that it's a real treat when something new and different comes out. For example, the quiet, mysterious quiet girl with the hidden power/ personality. The shy, bookworm that secretly likes the guy. The dorky, geek loser that some how ends up becoming a hero. So yer, reckon this is a declining thing?
*Real Places in Anime. Okay, a lot of anime uses Japan as a stage for their stories but how realistic is that? One anime, His and Her Circumstances had an interesting closing credit where a camera went around a real school and I found myself looking with interest. Has anyone actually been there done that sort of thing? Are there some schools right next to little forests that have that hill with the single tree at its peak that overlooks towns that's always deserted. Are those Festivals really like that with the girls wearing Kimono's and that catch the fish came etc etc? Those historic places they visit are they accurately represented etc?.
*Anime effect on you. Has anyone seen an anime that's challenged them so much that it's affected them on a permanent basis? Like changed the way they see things, or themselves. If so, what anime and how? Could just be something that's disturbed you so much you could never really forget it. For example, for me, X tv. That show kinda stuck with me. The two different sides fighting for apocalypse. One wants to destroy man kind so that the earth can survive and reclaim her dominon and the other wants to save humans as well as the side argument, 'why is it wrong to kill someone?' that was brought up. Given the power, I still don't know if I'll fight for the dragon of earth or heaven.
*Anime language? Etto, anyone else ever watched too much anime and started using the different lingo's they use. eg. Nya, Un-oh, Ara Ara, Etto, (see if you can pick these) Baka Baka Baka! Some of them are annoying, that they are.

Skanks wrote: > Notice these subjects seem to go off subject pretty quick. Maybe if I > create one with a few points it'll be enough to hold interest nya on a > few at the same time or atleast create enough confusion on different > discussions being held on at the same time to blend in well with the > rest of the subject.
> *Anime and TV shows. > Other then the obvious, the fact that its animated and from Japan is > there any real difference anymore between anime and 'live action' TV? > Anyone seen Monster, its about a doctor who saves the life of a kid > who incidentally butchered his parents and grows up to become this > hell psycho killer and the doctor takes it on himself to hunt him > down. There style of animation is pretty normal and I'm watching it > thinking why is it animated. With such a broad range of topics and > themes for anime is there really a way we can describe what is anime > that makes it so special?

POST.QUOTE:
Well, Anime is recognized as an art form and a distinctively Japanese form of entertainment over in the Land of the Rising Sun. A majority of the shows on TV in Japan are animated. Most often its the unrestricted freedom to make the show look and feel the way you want it to that draws directors and producer towards using animation over doing something live action.
Tenchi Muyo is what got the ball rolling on Cartoon Network when the series aired on Toonami. At that time hundreds of Yahoo Groups related to the show popped up. Also, its the fault of US distributors that Anime gets promoted as kids shows like Naruto which is NOT a show for kids in actuality, nor was Tenchi Muyo. Here in the US too many people have been brainwashed to think that animated = kids show. That irks me something fierce. So now shows like Naruto have become Power Rangered and the only way to get Sailor Moon Super S is to import it.
American shows are the same way. There is some originality in a lot of shows but there are also a lot of "me too" shows where someone tries a different twist on the same genre. Say like harem anime for instance or love triangle anime. Then you get stuff that comes right out of left field like Bleach, Naruto, Ghost in the Shell: SAC and Paranoia Agent which are all pretty much 90% original.
Most anime/manga creators put real places in their shows. A lot use their home towns. For Rumiko Takahashi the setting of Ranma 1/2 was Nerima, which is a suburb of Tokyo. Jubaan, the setting for Sailor Moon was the series creator's home town, and Masaki Kajishima the creator of Tenchi Muyo lived in the mountains of Yokohama where the series takes place. I've seen live photos of the locals in Please Teacher, the pier at the lake, the store in town, and even the lookout tower that's seen in the series are all real places. Tokyo Tower is also another popular setting for anime and its is definitely real as well as several shrines and temples in Tokyo seen in many anime. Nekomi, Japan the setting for Ah! My Goddess and the university are real places too.
Anime changed me. It inspired me to see an outlet for my creative side and that's how I discovered fan fiction. I'm now a popular author over at fanfiction.net.
I've used Japanese language from time to time. Ja, ne? Baka!!!

POST.QUOTE:
I'd like to elaborate on this part because its a subject I'm familiar with. I know a few people from Japan in FFXI and they've all told me the same thing. Almost every day in Japan there is a festival of some kind going on in different cities and prefectures, most are local holidays celebrating historical events, religions ceremonies, and etc. etc. The wearing of kimonos as everyday where is rare in Japan except among those families who are strictly traditional in their ways. You'll more than often see girls in kimonos at festivals since its tradition. Of all the anime that's been out they tell me that Azumanga Daioh is the most realistic depiction of what life is like for young teenagers in Japan, as in the festivals, the school festivals, what girls wear at school, and so on and so forth.

"Michael \"TheZorch\" Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-10-15T16:13:00 I've yet to get it but I've seen it and tried it on other people's machines and its awesome. I played the original TeamFortress when it was a Quake mod back in the early 90's. You had to use GameSpy to find servers back then and then it would launch Quakeworld which was a version of Quake optimized for online play. Has anyone here tried it yet?
For those who don't know that TF2 is, its a remake of a classic mod for Id Software's Quake, but this time around it uses Valve's Source Engine which is used for Half-Life 2. Its online play between two or more teams, each player chooses a class; a Soldier who is just for fighting, a Engineer who can build automated turret guns, a Sniper, a Demolitionist who's main weapon is a grenade launcher and can blow upon walls with explosives, a Medic who can heal team members or give enemy tieam members fatal diseases, a Scout who can run really fast, can track enemies but doesn't have a lot of armor, and the Spy who can assume the likeness of a member of the opposing team to get past automated guns. Typical games are Capture the Flag or Domination where your team must control certain points of the map the longest to earn the most points.

POST.QUOTE:
Geneon was originally the anime DVD division of Pioneer before being splintered off into an independent subsidiary of Pioneer and given the name "Geneon". They did dubs, I don't think they actually did any of the animation. Most of the stuff they released was from AIC which made Tenchi Muyo, Ah! My Goddess and a lot of other big named shows.

TEXT.POST:
Skanks <skank...@gmail.com> 2008-01-23T12:04:06 Okay, I've finally caught up Naruto Shippuden and well.. I know I like to joke about overly long fighting sequences and nothing getting done.. Well, I grabbed a crap load at a lan, I missed an ep in the middle of it, and.. Well, I didnt notice. The 20 or so episodes I watched, I watched in an hour, fast forwading all the crap. Thats 20 x 22min eps, in a single hour, possible less, I dont know, didnt time it, I was at a LAN. (around 200 people/pcs connected together sharing files playing games) Serouisly, Naruto sits there in a battle, stays still, for 3 episodes. Why do these sorts of anime's do this? This series was pretty good, but looking back, not alot happens. Ninja Fights should be quick, and fast paced, not standing around for hours yelling.
Am I the only one dissapointed at this? The series had so much potential, much like Bleach did, each of them start up, and I think, awsome, I can watch this series for ages, and then bomb, it goes crap but still leaving the taunting over all villian in the shadows.
To make up for that dissapointment though, I have perhaps 20 new series from this lan, I havent seen. I've finally started watching Lucky Star, I like that one, its weird seeing character that look like 12 yr olds that are actually 17yr olds. Tsubasa Chronicle as well, I watched the first few eps before flying out, and besides being very confused (probably because Im confused actually) that there are characters that were killed in X (another anime) in it, Im rather looking forward to watching more when I get back.

POST.QUOTE:
I tried it. The game seemed pretty much similar to all of the other Korean MMOs I've tried. This one has a somewhat better graphics engine, its has effects like Bloom and Dynamic Lighting which are seen in Oblivion but don't take up nearly as much resources. It ran ok on my 5 year old computer.
I've recently been playing around with a community built game using the free open source Freespace 2 engine. Its called Beyond the Red Line, and its a 3D Battlestar Galactica space combat simulator. FS2 was and still is the king of 3D first person space sims. This group improved on the graphics engine to include particle effects, true Zero-G physics so your Vipers fly like the ones in the series, and the polygon count and texture resolution has been doubled. Its still a beta but so far I'm impressed with what they've done with it. Dogfights with Cylon Raiders are so cool!

"Michael Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-09-20T00:25:00 I noticed some things about Fiesta. A lot of the Korean MMORPGs all seem to be made with similar GUIs to WoW. They're all emulating the point&click system WoW has. The graphics were in a nice, cutesy anime style and the music is rather easy on the ears. After playing a little I found it was very similar to WoW in playstyle. WoW must be really popular in Korea. FFXI doesn't have this kind of interface. No mouse on the PS2. You get a mouse on the PC version but its used a bit differently and most times you never need to use it except in the login screen. "Michael Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-09-21T16:04:00 This isn't an Anime themed game but it is a free game. It used to be a sold in stores but now you can legally get the full version online for free.
Its "Starseige: Tribes", the first ever online FPS. This is the one that started it all before there was ever an Unreal Tournament or Quake III: Arena. Its an older game but people still play it and you don't have to have a very power machine to run it either. There are different player classes, each player has jump jets and there are vehicles you can pilot ... the first FPS to really have them actually. People are still making mods for Tribes also. You can get it here:
http://www.download.com/Starsiege-Tribes-full-install/3000-7453_4-102...
Another good one is "Digital Paint: Paintball 2". Its an online-only game where you play paintball without the bruises. Its built using the code from Quake II which was released on the GPL license. You're required to register a username and password on the game website to play online. This is designed to deter cheaters and people who use bots. Sound clips from Family Guy, the Simpsons, the Loony Tunes and various movies are used through the game. You'll probably be laughing your ass off so hard you'll get pwned the first five minutes of playing. Its not as easy as you might think, some of these guys are really fucking good and I'm a fair FPS player myself. I urge you give this one a try if you're never played FPSs online before.

BODY.HEADLINE: Another FREE Anime MMORPG...This one is actually pretty good.

TEXT.POST:
"Michael \"TheZorch\" Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2008-07-10T09:50:31 I saw an ad for another one of those FREE Korean MMORPGes with an anime theme over at FanFiction.net and decided to give it a try. Its called Fantasy Life Mabinogi, and while I've only played just a little of it since downloading it but the production quality as compared to other Korean MMOs I've played is very high. The game like many others from Korea is free to play with a shop to buy vanity items and premium services with extras you don't normally get with free accounts. From what I've researched about this game it like World of Warcraft meets Second Life meets Maple Story (only its 3D and not a 2D side-scroller). Music plays a big role in the game, you can compose your own music and share it with others, you can have pets, I believe you can build your own house and own your own land from what I've seen in videos, and a whole lot more which I haven't delved into yet. The characters you talk to upon first entering the game also talk about crafting, so this game has a crafting system too.
After you create your character (certain options require a premium account) the game starts with a musical opening credits sequence like from an anime and is very well done. You appear on a white platform in the sky and talk to a very cute young girl in a black Mandarin dress who tells you about the world you're in, gives you a letter of introduction to give to the chief of the first village you'll encounter and gives you a book which is a guide on how to do things in the game. You're immediately teleported down to the ground where you meet a girl with a big knight's helmet on your head. She gives you you're first sword, after talking with her you level up some by doing battle with raccoons that are trying to attack chickens. The sword is magical and talk to you and acts as a guide through the beginning of the game. Supposedly sometime afterward the sword leaves you on its own, but I haven't gotten that far yet. So far this one looks way more promising than many of the other so-so anime inspired MMOs from Korea I've tried. Here's the website address if you want to try it out:
http://mabinogi.nexon.net/
Nexon by the way is the same group that makes Maple Story! LOL
-- Michael "TheZorch" Haney thezo ... @gmail.com http://thezorch.googlepages.com/home AIM: thezo ... @gmail.com Yahoo IM: zorchhaney ICQ: 343230252 GoogleTalk: thezorch Skype Name: thezorch MSN Messeger: haneymich ... @hotmail.com:

"Waseem Laher" <wmla...@gmail.com> 2007-09-23T16:59:00 Thinking about what you said, while that may be true, the path that's taken to reach that end as well as all the consequences are something else. One game comes to mind. Valkyrie Profile 2. This game has, by far, one of the most realistic stories I've ever seen. Initially it seems like your cliche good bad fight but things change fast. Team members that you've developed and trusted showed darker sides and others even betray you and in the end there is no party that is good or bad. Believe or not the story revolves around love.
So I hate spoilers as your mind will always try to work towards that end as you're watching/playing. I prefer to keep an open mind when watching/playing to develop with the story as I go along, not to expect the 'good' guys or 'bad' guys to win. I'll draw my own conclusions.

"Michael Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-09-23T22:07:00 On 9/23/07, Gold Dust Woman <goldustwo ... @gmail.com> wrote:
Many fans and the creator of the series consider "Death and Rebirth" and "End of Evangelion" to be the true endings to the EVA series. Usually a Director's Cut is made, like BlueAngel said, to add stuff that didn't appear in the original version. Usually its additional scenes added in like with LOTR or deleted scenes being put back in. Other times like with the original Star Trek movie and the original Star Wars trilogy a Director's Cut is where the filmmaker goes back and makes improvements. Some good and some not always so good. Anime is the same.

QUOTE.PREVIOUSPOST:
Skanks wrote: > Its been awhile since I've found a new decent anime. > This one seems to be based on Kendo as a sport. Its an interesting > incite. Although its girls kendo it doesnt appear to be Harrem or > ettchi. That is, the characters all all scantly dressed or anything.
> They'd only realised the 5th on when I was home last. If you havent > already, check it out. Its pretty good and I'll look forward to the > continued releases. > Its basically a sport/comedy anime more then fighting.

POST.QUOTE:
There's another girls sports anime that seems rather interesting. I haven't seen much of it other than a preview of episode 1. Its Princess Nine, a tale of 9 girls who compete in a Japanese high school baseball championship and their principle who is trying to change the sexist rules of Japanese society. A lot of places I've looked to find reviews highly recommend it.
Another really good non-eechi, non-harem girls inspirational anime is CLAMP's Angelic Layer. A tale about a young middle schooler who moves to Tokyo to try to be near her mother and gets involved in a game that uses tiny robotic battle dolls. Though she is small and not athletic, in Angelic Layer none of this matters and she soon rises up the ranks until she reaches the national championship making lots of friends along the way. Its a 26 episode series that's been out for a while from ADV, the animation is top notch, the English dub is really good for a change, and the music is above average. We'd expect nothing less from a CLAMP anime though. Has anyone seen the manga that inspired this series?

THIS IS A SPOILER! Scroll down if you want to see ... did this so I don't ruin it for people who haven't watched Angelic Layer yet.
Angelic Layer, the game, was developed as part of a research project to create full-articulated artificial legs for people who are paralyzed. The sales of the toys, in the anime, pays for the development of the technology. Misaki's mother has a condition effecting her nervous system making it hard if not impossible to walk. She's the champion of Angelic Layer, and her work with the creator of the game helps further the project along. Eventually she gets the first of the new mentally controlled artificial legs so she can walk again by the end of the series.
-- Michael "TheZorch" Haney thezo ... @gmail.com http://thezorch.googlepages.com/home AIM: thezo ... @gmail.com Yahoo IM: zorchhaney ICQ: 343230252 GoogleTalk: thezorch MSN Messeger: haneymich ... @hotmail.com:

Well, the main point of the story is on Misaki becoming a better person as she advances through the game. I guess I can sympathize with you on this one, there's a similar anime called "Air Gear" and I just can't get into it for some reason. I wasn't able to get into Yugioh either even though I like playing those kinds of card games. There is a card battle game that's been around for a lot longer than the Yugioh card game from the anime that you can play in real life. That game is "Magic the Gathering", and there's an even older one I used to play called "Vampire the Masquerade" (originally called Jihad until its name was changed to the same name as the role-playing game it was based on).
I do believe the Vampire card game predates Pokemon and isn't just a one-on-one battle game but it incorporates political intrigue and requires a great deal more strategy to play. It was a fun game.

POST.QUOTE:
Technically, the answer is YES. According to existing Copyright laws ... which the Digital Millennium Copyright Act contradicts left and right and opens massive loopholes which allow unethical corporations to abuse the law to stifle legitimate competitors. Its a fatal flaw in the DMCA which has contributed to some of the downfall of our economy. It needs to be abolished. DMCA abuse is common, and until the current administration is out of the White House we'll see nothing done about the problem until after the 2008 elections.
Also, another loophole in the DMCA actually "shields" Youtube and other similar video services from most of the more serious copyright issues because they don't let you download and store the content you watch but just stream it. As long as the video isn't stored longterm on your computer these sites is ... under the DMCA and according to the Library of Congress who's job it is to interpret the DMCA ... legal. That doesn't mean copyright owners can't ask Youtube or Veoh to remove videos from their website, but it shields those websites from most lawsuits.

There's a famous photo of Nixon coming off of Air Force One in Japan flashing the "V" sign after his peace mission to China in the 1960's. "V" for Victory was also popularized after the successful landing at Normandy in WWII by the allies.

TEXT.POST:
"Michael Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2007-10-03T09:51:00 After doing some research I discovered a few things about the closure of Geneon I've mentioned on her before. The entire company is not shutting down. Geneon is closing down their DVD production division and signed a deal with ADV to press and distribute DVDs for them. Geneon will continue to work on their existing projects but their release dates will be changed because of this shift. So, Geneon is still around, they'll just be releasing their stuff through ADV.

The new article at AnimeNewsNetwork.com: ===== Funimation's New One Piece Dub Starts Saturday Cartoon Network will premiere Funimation's new English dubbing of Toei Animation and Shonen Jump's One Piece pirate adventure anime series in the United States on Saturday, September 29 at 10:00 p.m. ET. The Saturday showing will restart the series from where 4Kids Entertainment, the former licensee, ended its adaptation and begin the story arc known as the Skypiea Saga. The new dub features Colleen Clinkenbeard as the rubber-bodied captain Monkey D. Luffy and Christopher R. Sabat as the swordsman Roronoa Zolo. =====
FUNimation used to be like 4Kids, but the release of Tenchi Muyo GXP and the unedited Dragonball Z DVDs redeemed them of that distinction.

QUOTE.PREVIOUSPOST: Joanna Tsui wrote: > hn, maybe. but i hate dubs. especially the way they say the names =_="

POST.QUOTE:
Some people do nit pick at that. My nit pick is when a dub "changes" character names like changing Usagi in Sailor Moon to Serena and Momaru to Darian.
A friend of mine nit picks about Steel Angel Karumi. In English her name is pronounced "Ka-roo-me" but in Japanese her name is actually pronounced as "Ka-doo-me" because the "r" in a Japanese Romanji (Japanese words using the Roman Alphabet) word has a "d" sound unless its at the beginning of the word.

QUOTE.PREVIOUSPOST: Gold Dust Woman wrote: > oh, and what does dattebayo mean?

POST.QUOTE:
Found this on the web. This is why Japanese is so fucking hard to translate or learn because words often convey abstract meanings rather than having a literal meaning.
========== In the Japanese versions, Naruto often ends his sentences with "dattebayo" or "(verb)-ttebayo" ;, and as such Naruto has a unique style of speech. In the Japanese language, an ending can be added with no meaning to make the tone sound more tough, childish, girlish, or many other changes depending on the many existing endings. "-ttebayo", which is not a well-known ending, has no literal meaning and cannot be translated, but carries the connotations of the speaker being uncultured, brusque, and seeming tougher than they really are.In the English anime and video games, he often says "Believe it!" to fit with the mouth flaps of "-ttebayo".

"Michael \"TheZorch\" Haney" <thezo...@gmail.com> 2008-07-18T22:25:00 Is it me or do Media Blasters DVDs suck toilet water? My roomie has "Figure 17" and "12 Kingdoms" and neither the DVD player in the living room nor the DVD drives in our PCs will play them right. Our friend who owns a Mac checked the disks and found something interesting. Media Blasters doesn't separate out the videos of each episode into different .vob DVD MPEG2 video files on the disk like, oh I don't know .... EVERYONE ELSE!!!! No, they put ALL of the episodes into one big video file and time coded it to add chapter bookmarks. That's fine, movies are done that way, but their MPEG2 encoding is piss poor. Where the hell did they get the software to encode their video, from a box of Fruit Loops?! The video software on our friend's Mac found encoding errors all through the disks, errors which make the videos skip or lock up when we try to play them in our DVD player on on our PCs. We did check for scratches but the disks aren't physically damaged.
So, we're trying to watch "12 Kingdoms" because it looks like a really interesting show, but we gotta jump through some major hoops to do so. Basically, our friend with the Mac has to rip the DVD using software that can correct for the errors and convert them over to iTunes .mp4 format which is playable on an iPod or Apple TV. The video quality is the same as the DVD with no degrading in frame rate or sound quality. Anyway, its pretty sad that we have to do that in order to enjoy a anime.
Do any of you have problems with Media Blasters DVDs? I've checked around we don't seem to be the only one's with this complaint.
-- Michael "TheZorch" Haney thezo ... @gmail.com http://thezorch.googlepages.com/home AIM: thezo ... @gmail.com Yahoo IM: zorchhaney ICQ: 343230252 GoogleTalk: thezorch Skype Name: thezorch MSN Messeger: haneymich ... @hotmail.com:
